title: How to Make Homemade Jello

steps.headline: Combine the juice, water, and agar agar.
steps.description: Get out a small saucepan and pour in 1 ½ cups (355 ml) of juice, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water and 1 tablespoon agar agar flakes OR 1 teaspoon agar agar powder. Stir the mixture to combine the ingredients. You can use any juice except for pineapple juice. Pineapple contains enzymes that will prevent the jello from setting up.

steps.headline: Boil and dissolve the jello mixture.
steps.description: Turn the heat on to high and bring the jello mixture to a boil. Boil the mixture for 5 minutes and stir it occasionally. This will help dissolve the agar agar. Turn off the heat. If you want sweeter jello, you can stir in 1 to 2 tablespoons of honey.

steps.headline: Arrange fruit in the dish.
steps.description:
Peel and slice 1 to 2 cups (175 to 350 g) of fresh fruit. Lay it in the bottom of an 8x8-inch (20x20-cm) baking dish. Avoid using raw fruits that have enzymes which prevent the jello from setting up (or you can just cook them first). These fruits include:
Pineapple
Kiwi
Mango
Fig
Guava
Ginger root
Pawpaw

steps.headline: Pour and chill the vegan jello.
steps.description: Slowly pour the jello over the fruit. Put the baking dish in the refrigerator and chill the jello for 4 hours or until the jello is firm. You can slice the jello into squares and serve them immediately. Or you can use cookie cutters to make unique jello shapes. For example, you can cut stars, hearts, circles, or festive shapes.

steps.headline: Combine the juice with the gelatin.
steps.description: Measure 2 cups (473 ml) of juice into a small saucepan and stir in 2 tablespoons of grass-fed pasture-raised gelatin. Keep stirring until the gelatin is dissolved. Try to use the highest quality gelatin you can find. These will contain more nutrients than standard gelatin that's in most jello mixes.

steps.headline: Heat the jello mixture.
steps.description: Heat the saucepan over medium until the jello mixture starts to bubble gently. Simmer the mixture for 10 minutes and stir it occasionally. Turn off the heat and let it sit for a few minutes. Don't let the jello sit for more than 5 minutes, since it could begin to set up and clump.

steps.headline: Slice the fruit and season the jello.
steps.description: Peel and slice your favorite fruit, so you get 1/2 to 1 cup (90 to 175 g) of sliced fruit. For example, you could use peaches, bananas, strawberries, or plums. Taste the jello and add a little sweetener, if you like. To sweeten the jello, consider using a few tablespoons of raw honey, coconut nectar or stevia.

steps.headline: Pour and chill the healthier jello.
steps.description: Arrange the fruit in the bottom of a glass baking dish or jello mold. Pour the jello mixture over the fruit and put the dish or mold in the refrigerator. Chill the jello for 3 to 4 hours, so it sets up completely. You can slice or scoop out the jello to serve it. You can refrigerate the jello overnight to help it firm up.

methods.name: Making Homemade Jello With Strawberry Fruit Puree

steps.headline: Sprinkle the gelatin over the cold water.
steps.description: Get out a small prep bowl and pour 1/4 cup (60 ml) of cold water into it. Sprinkle 1 scant tablespoon of gelatin (or 1 packet) over the cold water. Set the gelatin mixture aside for 5 to 10 minutes. Avoid stirring the gelatin while it hydrates. This could make it clump.

steps.headline: Whisk hot water into the gelatin mixture.
steps.description: Transfer the gelatin mixture into a medium mixing bowl. Slowly whisk 1/4 cup (60 ml) of hot (but not boiling) water into the gelatin. Keep whisking until the gelatin dissolves completely.

steps.headline: Puree the strawberries with the sugar and lime juice.
steps.description: Wash and trim the stems from 2 pints (680 g) of strawberries. Place these into a blender or food processor along with 1/4 to 1/2 cup (50 to 100 g) of sugar. For a tangier jello, you can also juice 1/2 of a lime and pour the juice in. Puree the ingredients until they're smooth. You can also use frozen strawberries. Defrost them before putting them in the blender.

steps.headline: Strain the puree into the gelatin mixture.
steps.description: Place a metal strainer over the bowl and pour the strawberry puree into it. The strainer will catch most of the pulp and seeds. You may need to use a rubber spatula to gently press the puree against the strainer. This will push the juice through the strainer into the bowl. You can discard the seeds and strawberry pulp in the strainer.

steps.headline: Chill the homemade jello.
steps.description: Pour the jello mixture into a jello mold, baking dish, or individual serving bowls. Put the jello in the refrigerator and chill the jello for 4 hours or until it's set. Serve the jello once it's firm. You can slice the jello or scoop it out of the bowl. Consider serving the jello with fresh whipped cream.

text:
Making Homemade Jello Without Gelatin (Vegan) Combine the juice, water, and agar agar. Get out a small saucepan and pour in 1 ½ cups (355 ml) of juice, 1/2 cup (120 ml) of water and 1 tablespoon agar agar flakes OR 1 teaspoon agar agar powder. Stir the mixture to combine the ingredients. You can use any juice except for pineapple juice. Pineapple contains enzymes that will prevent the jello from setting up. Boil and dissolve the jello mixture. Turn the heat on to high and bring the jello mixture to a boil. Boil the mixture for 5 minutes and stir it occasionally. This will help dissolve the agar agar. Turn off the heat. If you want sweeter jello, you can stir in 1 to 2 tablespoons of honey. Arrange fruit in the dish. Peel and slice 1 to 2 cups (175 to 350 g) of fresh fruit. Lay it in the bottom of an 8x8-inch (20x20-cm) baking dish. Avoid using raw fruits that have enzymes which prevent the jello from setting up (or you can just cook them first). These fruits include:
Pineapple
Kiwi
Mango
Fig
Guava
Ginger root
Pawpaw Pour and chill the vegan jello. Slowly pour the jello over the fruit. Put the baking dish in the refrigerator and chill the jello for 4 hours or until the jello is firm. You can slice the jello into squares and serve them immediately. Or you can use cookie cutters to make unique jello shapes. For example, you can cut stars, hearts, circles, or festive shapes. Making Healthier Homemade Jello Combine the juice with the gelatin. Measure 2 cups (473 ml) of juice into a small saucepan and stir in 2 tablespoons of grass-fed pasture-raised gelatin. Keep stirring until the gelatin is dissolved. Try to use the highest quality gelatin you can find. These will contain more nutrients than standard gelatin that's in most jello mixes. Heat the jello mixture. Heat the saucepan over medium until the jello mixture starts to bubble gently. Simmer the mixture for 10 minutes and stir it occasionally. Turn off the heat and let it sit for a few minutes. Don't let the jello sit for more than 5 minutes, since it could begin to set up and clump. Slice the fruit and season the jello. Peel and slice your favorite fruit, so you get 1/2 to 1 cup (90 to 175 g) of sliced fruit. For example, you could use peaches, bananas, strawberries, or plums. Taste the jello and add a little sweetener, if you like. To sweeten the jello, consider using a few tablespoons of raw honey, coconut nectar or stevia. Pour and chill the healthier jello. Arrange the fruit in the bottom of a glass baking dish or jello mold. Pour the jello mixture over the fruit and put the dish or mold in the refrigerator. Chill the jello for 3 to 4 hours, so it sets up completely. You can slice or scoop out the jello to serve it. You can refrigerate the jello overnight to help it firm up. Making Homemade Jello With Strawberry Fruit Puree Sprinkle the gelatin over the cold water. Get out a small prep bowl and pour 1/4 cup (60 ml) of cold water into it. Sprinkle 1 scant tablespoon of gelatin (or 1 packet) over the cold water. Set the gelatin mixture aside for 5 to 10 minutes. Avoid stirring the gelatin while it hydrates. This could make it clump. Whisk hot water into the gelatin mixture. Transfer the gelatin mixture into a medium mixing bowl. Slowly whisk 1/4 cup (60 ml) of hot (but not boiling) water into the gelatin. Keep whisking until the gelatin dissolves completely. Puree the strawberries with the sugar and lime juice. Wash and trim the stems from 2 pints (680 g) of strawberries. Place these into a blender or food processor along with 1/4 to 1/2 cup (50 to 100 g) of sugar. For a tangier jello, you can also juice 1/2 of a lime and pour the juice in. Puree the ingredients until they're smooth. You can also use frozen strawberries. Defrost them before putting them in the blender. Strain the puree into the gelatin mixture. Place a metal strainer over the bowl and pour the strawberry puree into it. The strainer will catch most of the pulp and seeds. You may need to use a rubber spatula to gently press the puree against the strainer. This will push the juice through the strainer into the bowl. You can discard the seeds and strawberry pulp in the strainer. Chill the homemade jello. Pour the jello mixture into a jello mold, baking dish, or individual serving bowls. Put the jello in the refrigerator and chill the jello for 4 hours or until it's set. Serve the jello once it's firm. You can slice the jello or scoop it out of the bowl. Consider serving the jello with fresh whipped cream. Finished.
